title: 111_s3418
content: The Act is titled the "Comprehensive Problem Gambling Act of 2010" and includes findings related to problem gambling. The "Comprehensive Problem Gambling Act of 2010" finds that problem gambling is a public health disorder with serious consequences, affecting over 6,000,000 adults last year. The social cost of problem gambling was $6,700,000,000, leading to bankruptcy, divorce, job loss, and criminal justice costs. Problem gambling is linked to bankruptcy, domestic abuse, suicide, and co-occurring substance abuse and mental health disorders. The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration is the lead Federal agency for substance abuse and mental health services, while there are no agencies or individuals in the Federal Government with formal responsibility for problem gambling. Many States are considering expanding legal gambling activities to raise State revenues due to budget shortfalls. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include programs for identifying, preventing, and treating problem gambling. Additionally, there are no formal responsibilities for addressing problem gambling at the Federal level, despite the potential expansion of legal gambling activities in many States. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include programs for researching, preventing, and addressing problem gambling through public awareness initiatives. The Secretary will conduct a national campaign to raise awareness about problem gambling, including supporting existing campaigns and creating public service announcements. Additionally, voluntary donations may be coordinated to assist in implementing new programs and supporting national campaigns through various media channels. The Secretary will conduct a national campaign to raise awareness about problem gambling, targeting radio and television audiences of sporting and gambling events. Evaluation of the campaign's effectiveness will be conducted, with a report submitted to the President and Congress. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out these activities. Authorization of $200,000 for fiscal years 2011-2015 is provided for carrying out activities related to raising awareness about problem gambling through a national campaign. The Secretary will establish a national research program on problem gambling, considering recommendations from the National Gambling Impact Study Commission. $4,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2011 to 2015. Additionally, there is a provision for prevention and treatment in section 597B. The Secretary will provide grants to entities for comprehensive services related to problem gambling issues and education. Eligible entities must submit an application to receive a grant. The Secretary will also develop a treatment improvement protocol specific to problem gambling. Authorization of appropriations is provided for these purposes. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out comprehensive services related to problem gambling issues and education, with $10,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year from 2011 through 2015.
